text: in this week's movies acod a touch of
sin and gravity gravity is a 3d movie
about the struggle for survival in
terrible rapidly changing circumstances
and his review AO scott reitz as our
eyes adjust to the vast darkness we
detect movement that is recognizably
human and hear familiar voices
astronauts movie stars Sandra Bullock
and George Clooney in spacesuits the
main challenge facing the director
Alfonso Quran is not visualizing the
unimaginable so much as overcoming the
audience's assumption that we've seen it
all before mr. Quran succeeds by
tethering almost unfathomably complex
techniques both digital and analog to a
simple narrative gravity is less
science-fiction spectacle than a jack
london tale in orbit the standard for a
movie like this one is not realism but
coherence every true outlaw has a code
the laws of physics are no exception and
mr. Quran violates them with ingenious
and exuberant rigor
a touch of sin is a fictionalised tail
straight out of china in her review
Manohla Dargis writes that a touch of
sin is a story of lives rocked by
violence it's inscribed with visual
lyricism emotional weight and a belief
in individual rights divided into four
sections each centered on a different
character the movie opens in a northern
town where a man has started a solitary
campaign against the village leader and
the local boss who have grown rich
selling communal property what about you
Paige yah oh yah husband moment what
concerns him or people exploited and
dehumanized by others who now only value
things like the private plane that the
big boss spies and other shiny totems of
new China the transformation of
characters is of a piece with the
everyday surrealism that the director
Joe juhnke finds in cities villages and
along highways there's no current
research about people like you people
like me a CEO DS adult children of
divorce acod is an unfunny comedy about
a guy mooning over his parents divorce
decades after it occurs you have turned
a nine-year marriage into a hundred year
war in her review Manohla Dargis writes
the movie is so eager to please it's
hard to hate but it's sluggish even at
87 minutes cliched and gives you nothing
of interest to look at other than some
familiar faces were part of a book club
Adam Scott a likeable presence no matter
the material plays carters a restaurant
tour in a generic town what matters in
this movie is Carter his needs his
emotions and most of all his unhappiness
with his parents I do know that director
Stuart zukerman has rounded up an
affable group of actors including Amy
Poehler who nimbly rises above her
shrewish caricature she's meant to play
ringing out some much-needed laughs
Jane Lynch who plays a woman studying
children of divorce also elevates her
scene pick nits with me are but mr.
Zuckerman needs a better crew some time
with the criterion collection and
fresher story I got what I needed thank
you and I'll see you next week this is
great
